QAPair.Question: What is (are) Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: The optic nerve carries images of what the eye sees to the brain. When this nerve become swollen or inflamed, it is called optic neuritis. It may cause sudden, reduced vision in the affected eye.

QAPair.Question: What causes Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: The exact cause of optic neuritis is unknown. The optic nerve carries visual information from your eye to the brain. The nerve can swell when it becomes suddenly inflamed. The swelling can damage nerve fibers. This can cause short or long-term loss of vision. Conditions that have been linked with optic neuritis include: Autoimmune diseases , including lupus , sarcoidosis , and Behçet disease, Cryptococcosis , a fungal infection, Bacterial infections, including tuberculosis, syphilis, Lyme disease , and meningitis , Viral infections, including viral encephalitis , measles , rubella , chickenpox , herpes zoster , mumps , and mononucleosis, Respiratory infections, including mycoplasma pneumonia and other common upper respiratory tract infections, Multiple sclerosis ,

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms may include: Loss of vision in one eye over an hour or a few hours, Changes in the way the pupil reacts to bright light, Loss of color vision, Pain when you move the eye ,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: A complete medical exam can help rule out related diseases. Tests may include: Color vision testing, MRI of the brain , including special images of the optic nerve, Visual acuity testing , Visual field testing, Examination of the optic disc using indirect ophthalmoscopy ,

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Vision often returns to normal within 2 to 3 weeks with no treatment. Corticosteroids given through a vein (IV) or taken by mouth (oral) may speed up recovery. However, the final vision is no better with steroids than without. Oral steroids may actually increase the chance of recurrence. If tests suggest that there is also multiple sclerosis, certain forms of interferon may be helpful. Further tests may be needed to try to find the cause of the neuritis. If there is a condition causing the problem, it may be able to be treated.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: When optic neuritis occurs without other diseases, there is a better prognosis. An MRI is an important test because it can help predict if multiple sclerosis or other similar autoimmune diseases are present or may develop. Optic neuritis caused by multiple sclerosis or other autoimmune diseases has a poorer outlook. However, vision in the affected eye may still return to normal.

QAPair.Question: What are the complications of Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Complications may include: Body-wide side effects from corticosteroids, Vision loss , Some people who have an episode of optic neuritis will develop nerve problems in other places in the body or develop multiple sclerosis.

Question.qtype: when to contact a medical professional

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Optic neuritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your health care provider right away if you have a sudden loss of vision in one eye, especially if you have eye pain. If you have been diagnosed with optic neuritis, contact your health care provider if: Your vision decreases., The pain in the eye gets worse., Your symptoms do not improve within 2 to 3 weeks. ,
